Solvent or hydrothermal synthesis of MOF requires more energy. Therefore, based on the synthesis of MOF at room temperature, CuOx/C catalyst was prepared by calcination, and related researches were carried out with the goal of removing NOx. The effects of different calcination time and calcination temperature on the denitration performance of the catalyst were studied, and the optimal preparation conditions were screened. And through the characterization and analysis of XRD, FTIR, SEM and XPS, the difference in denitration performance of the catalyst under different calcination conditions was explained. Combined with the calculation of HSC Chemistry software, it is shown that NO would react differently on the catalyst at different temperatures. Which was also an important reason for the need to improve the selectivity of catalysts at low temperatures. Environmental Implication NOx is one of the main gas pollutants, and the current treatment method mainly uses ammonia gas as a reducing agent to remove it under the action of the catalyst. Through the action of catalyst, NOx can react with ammonia gas to generate harmless nitrogen gas. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) Derived carbon-based catalyst Chemical thermodynamic Catalytic mechanism Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the development of environmental functional materials, more and more up-to-date materials have been researched and developed [1,2]. Among them, metal organic frameworks (MOFs), with high specific surface area, highly dispersed metal active centers, and regular pores, have attracted extensive attention since it was successfully synthesized [3,4]. Benefiting from its rich specific surface area and pore structure, most researchers use it as an adsorbent in the field of environmental protection [5,6]. Cu-BTC is a well-studied MOF material commonly synthesized by solvothermal methods, also known as HKUST-1 [7,8]. The large number of active sites and metal particles contained in MOFs materials are the main reasons for their use as catalysts [9]. In order to reduce the adsorption effect of MOFs pores, as the precursor material containing metal activity and abundant C-H structure, has become a new hot spot in the development of catalytic materials [10,11]. Although there have been some studies on the use of Cu-BTC for low-temperature denitration in recent years, the application of the derived carbon-based copper oxide in the direction of denitration is relatively rare [12,13]. At present, for the removal of NOx in flue gas, SCR technology is the main method [14,15]. And the key to SCR denitration catalysts lies in the selection of carriers and active components, as well as the control of denitration temperature [16,17]. The coal-fired flue gas enters the SCR denitration unit after wet desulfurization, and the catalyst needs to have good low temperature denitration performance [18,19]. To reduce the energy consumption during material preparation, the author's team successfully synthesized Cu-BTC at room temperature using a milder and cleaner method, and it performed well in low-temperature denitration [20]. Therefore, in order to further study the low-temperature denitration performance of Cu-BTC-derived carbon materials, it was studied based on the preferred preparation process conditions in the previous study. It provided the application basis for MOFs materials and their applications in the field of low temperature denitration. The HSC Chemistry software was used to calculate the ΔH and Gibbs free energies of the possible reactions in the system and the half-reactions on the catalyst, and the main paths of the reaction process were obtained. Combined with the XPS surface element analysis before and after the catalyst was used, the mechanism of the reaction was obtained. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of CuOx/C Based on the previous research of the team, Cu-BTC was synthesized by hydrothermal method [21]. On this basis, in order to reduce the preparation energy consumption, Cu-BTC was self-assembled at room temperature under milder conditions, and the preparation conditions were optimized [22]. In this paper, the carbon-based catalyst was prepared by calcination using the Cu-BTC synthesized at room temperature as the precursor. The specific preparation process is shown in the Fig. 1 . First, the catalysts with different calcination time (1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 h) were prepared under the condition of calcination temperature of 300 °C, which were named CuOx/C-1 h, CuOx/C-2 h, CuOx/C-3 h, CuOx/C-4 h and CuOx/C-5 h. Through the performance test, it was found that the denitration performance was better when the calcination time was 3 h. Therefore, catalysts with different calcination temperatures (300, 350, 400, 450 and 500 °C) were subsequently prepared and studied, which were named CuOx/C-300 °C, CuOx/C-350 °C, CuOx/C-400 °C, CuOx/C-450 °C and CuOx/C-500 °C. 2.2 Denitration performance test of CuOx/C SCR denitration was carried out in a fixed bed reactor with a temperature range of 120∼300 °C. The gas composition was NO 500 ppm, NH3 500 ppm, O2 6%, with N2 balanced. The gas flow was 300 mL/min and the volumetric space velocity was 40,000 h−1. The specific device process can be found in reference. 2.3 Analytical methods XD-3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyzer (produced by Beijing Puxi General Instrument Co., Ltd.) was used with Co, Kα (1.54056 Å), and radiation at 36 kV and 20 mA. The Fourier infrared spectrometer (FT-IR) used is produced by Bruker (VERTEX 70). The X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) used is ESCALAB250 (produced by Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA), with the energy resolution 0.45 eV (Ag), and the sensitivity 180 KCPS. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) is JSM-6460LV (produced by JEOL Ltd.) with the energy dispersive spectrum. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 XRD Shown in the Fig. 2 (a) and (b), there are obvious diffraction peaks of CuO and Cu2O on the CuOx/C catalysts. It is consistent with the previous report [23], that is the derivatives prepared by Cu-BTC in the atmosphere of oxygen and air, and the crystal phases formed are CuO and Cu2O. And CuO has the diffraction peaks with narrower half-peak width and higher peak intensity, indicating that the generated CuO has higher crystallinity. But due to the distribution of oxygen in the air and the contact between oxygen and Cu, the generated derivative will be some incompletely oxidized Cu2O in the material. Zhao et al. [24] prepared MOF derived CuOx/C by pyrolysis under nitrogen atmosphere and discovered metallic Cu phase, which is due to the self-reduction of Cu2+ to lower valence copper species during the pyrolysis of Cu-BTC. The MOF-derived Cu2O/Cu nanospheres prepared under Ar atmosphere only formed Cu2O and Cu species even at high temperature [25]. Therefore, when the calcination time is short, due to the incomplete reaction between the precursor and oxygen, the Cu in the precursor retains an appropriate amount of Cu2O phase under the reduction effect of organic ligands. The content of Cu2O decreases with the increase of calcination temperature, which is because the generated Cu2O will further react with O2 to form CuO. By comparing the PDF cards, it can be seen that the generated CuO is Tenorite (PDF#89-2529), and Cu2O is Cuprite (PDF#77-0199). The derivatives correspond to (110), (002), (111), (-202), (020), (202), (-113) and (220) crystal planes of CuO at 32.488°, 35.436°, 38.667°, 48.840°, 53.398°, 58.204°, 61.578° and 68.036°, respectively. Meanwhile, 36.520°, 42.422°, 61.550° and 73.737° correspond to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal of Cu2O, respectively. 3.1.2 FTIR The characteristic peaks of Cu-BTC are different from those prepared by traditional hydrothermal or solvent methods, which is mainly due to the formation of different functional groups of organic ligands for the temperature and pressure of the synthesis system [26,27]. However, the CuOx/C catalysts retained the original characteristic absorption peaks of the Cu-BTC synthesized at room temperature [22]. And they are shown in the Fig. 3 (a) and (b). The C=C=O double bond in the carboxyl group of the ligand is retained near 2360 and 2341 cm−1, and its characteristic peak intensity is strengthened compared with Cu-BTC [28]. 1652 cm−1 is attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration peak of the carboxylic acid, while 1558 cm−1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the carboxyl group [29]. The out-of-plane bending vibration absorption of C-H is near 669 cm−1. And around 517 cm−1 is the stretching vibration peak of the bond related to copper coordination [30], and it is also an important fingerprint region for the formation of Cu oxides on the catalyst, which corresponds to the crystal structure CuO and Cu2O in XRD patterns. 3.1.3 XPS The prepared CuOx/C-450 °C catalyst (CuOx/C(fresh)) and the catalyst recovered after denitration (CuOx/C(used)) were analyzed by XPS. As shown in Fig. 4 , the surface elements of the CuOx/C(fresh) and CuOx/C(used) were tested by XPS, and the Avantage software was used for charge correction and peak fitting. From the full spectrum of Fig. 4(a), the main elements on the catalyst surface are C, O and Cu. Fig. 4(b) is the peak-splitting spectrum of C 1s. On the surface of CuOx/C(fresh), the characteristic peaks observed with binding energy around 284.8, 285.4 and 288.6 eV are the corresponding sp2 hybridized graphitic carbon, sp3 hybridized amorphous carbon and C=O double carbon, respectively. Meanwhile, the binding energy at 284.8, 286.3 and 288.6 eV of CuOx/C(used) corresponds sp2, sp3 and C=O carbon [31]. Also, the C=O double bond is due to the retention of the precursor during calcination, which can also be illustrated in the FTIR spectrum of CuOx/C catalysts. Fig. 4(c) is the peak spectrum of O 1s, the peaks with the binding energies at around 531.5, 530.2 and 529.6 eV are assigned to surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα), surface lattice oxygen (Oβ1) and surface lattice oxygen (Oβ2), respectively [32]. CuOx/C(fresh) at the binding energy of 529.6 eV is characteristic of oxygen in a metal oxide such as Cu2O or CuO [33]. The 530.2 eV peak is attributed to C=O bond, which is consistent with the results in C 1s [34]. 531.5 eV is mainly the adsorbed water molecules in the material [35]. Similarly, the corresponding binding energy on CuOx/C(used) are slightly shifted, with peaks at 529.7 eV, 531 eV and 532.1 eV, respectively [36]. Fig. 4(d) shows the peak spectrum of Cu 2p. For the Cu 2p3/2 spectrum of CuOx/C(fresh), characteristic peaks are around 933.5 and 934.9 eV, corresponding to Cu+ and Cu2+ [37]. The characteristic peaks of CuOx/C(used) around 933.4 and 934.7 eV are corresponding to Cu+ and Cu2+ [24,25]. Characteristic peaks (941.4 and 944.0 eV) located at low binding energy are assigned to satellite peaks [38]. The results of XPS detection are consistent with the results of XRD. The copper in the catalyst is mainly Cu+ and Cu2+. Consistent with the results of the O 1s peak spectrum in Fig. 4(c), it shows that the Cu-O structure has stable performance before and after the catalyst used, and mainly plays a catalytic role. From the XPS calculation results in Table 1 , the redox electron pair formed by Cu+ and Cu2+ undergoes electron transfer in the SCR reaction, thereby improving the denitration performance [26]. Furthermore, a reduction of the surface oxygen atom concentration is observed from Oα on the catalysts, proving that the reaction of the catalyst occurs with the consumption of surface oxygen [32]. 3.1.4 SEM Fig. 5 shows the morphology and structure of Cu-BTC synthesized at room temperature, in which Fig. 5(a) and (f) are under different magnifications. It shows the synthesized Cu-BTC has the crystal structure, with the typical Cu-BTC structures of octahedron and dodecahedron with width in the range of 10–20 μm. However, due to the mild conditions at room temperature, the irregular crystal structure is also formed. EDS and mapping show that the Cu-BTC sample has C, O and Cu elements, and the element ratio is relatively stable, indicating that the formed Cu-BTC has a relatively stable structure. Fig. 6 is the morphological structure of the Cu-BTC-derived catalyst CuOx/C with the calcination time of 3 h and the calcination temperature of 450 °C (The catalyst CuOx/C-450 °C with the best denitration performance), in which Fig. 6(a) and (f) are under different magnifications. The catalyst retains part of the typical octahedral structure of Cu-BTC, but the overall width is reduced to 5–10 μm. There are also some crystal particles agglomerated into larger blocks due to calcination, which may also be caused by the agglomeration of precursors. The EDS and mapping of the catalyst show that the ratio of C, O and Cu elements is relatively stable, and the content of Cu element is increased compared with that of the precursor, while the C element is decreased. 3.2 Effect of calcination conditions on denitration performance of catalysts Fig. 7 (a) and (b) show the denitration performance of catalysts prepared at different calcination times, while Fig. 7(c) and (d) show it at different calcination temperatures. Fig. 7(b) and (d) are the statistical graphs of Fig. 7(a) and 7(c), respectively, which are shown in boxplots and distribution charts in Fig. 7(b) and (d). From Fig. 7(a), the denitration performance of the catalysts first increase and then decrease with the increase of calcination time. When the temperature is above 240 °C, the catalytic performance of CuOx/C-3 h was the best, exceeding 80%. It can be seen from Fig. 7(b) that the average and median denitration values of the catalyst CuOx/C-3 h are higher than those of other catalysts, and there are many points where the catalytic efficiency is distributed over 80%. Therefore, combined with XRD, FTIR and Fig. 7(a), the efficiency of this catalyst is due to others. Fig. 7(c) shows that the calcination temperature also greatly affects the performance of the catalyst, and its performance increases with the increase of the calcination temperature [39]. The denitration of CuOx/C-450 °C catalyst exceeds 80% when the temperature is above 240 °C, while it is up to 90% over 300 °C. The average and median denitration values of the catalyst CuOx/C-3 h are higher than those of other catalysts in Fig. 8 (d). Therefore, referring to Fig. 8(c), this catalyst has the best denitration efficiency. Fig. 8 shows the performance of catalyst CuOx/C-450 °C(optimum denitration rate) about sulfur and water resistance. It can be seen from Fig. 8(a) that the denitration can be stabilized for 10 min before SO2 is introduced. After the system is stable for 30 min, the denitration begins to decrease with 500 ppm SO2 introduced, and the denitration rate is regionally balanced with the continuous introduction of SO2 for 10 min. After the SO2 is stopped, the denitration rate rebounds. Since SO2 is a substance that caused catalyst poisoned, the denitration rate does not fully recover to that before the introduction of SO2. Fig. 8(b) shows the water resistance performance of the catalyst that the denitration rate decreases after the introduction of H2O. And the denitration rate basically returns to the original denitration rate after the H2O is cut off, so the catalyst has excellent water resistance performance. 3.3 Mechanism analysis of denitration 3.3.1 Chemical thermodynamic analysis of possible processes in the reaction system The NO in the reaction system can show a certain reducibility due to the presence of O2, so the ΔH and ΔG of the possible auto-oxidation reactions are compared by the HSC Chemistry 6.0 software, as shown in Fig. 9 . Fig. 9(a) shows the ΔH values of different reactions. The ΔH values of the seven different reactions are all less than 0, indicating that the reaction systems are all exothermic. Fig. 9(b) is the value of ΔG, and the values of all equations increase with the increase of temperature. But only when the value of ΔG is less than 0, that is N2O5 (below 169 °C), N2O3 (below 181 °C), N2O4 (below 259 °C), NO2 (below 494 °C) and N2O (below 723 °C), the reaction can proceed to the right. More by-products will be generated, which is the reason why SCR has lower denitration performance and poor selectivity at low temperature. Fig. 9(c) and (d) show ΔH and ΔG for the reactions of different reactants with NH3. The high valence NOx reacts preferentially to the NH3 reaction. In combination with Fig. 9(b), N2O2 and NO3 cannot be formed spontaneously and therefore do not react with NH3. And when the temperature is above 300 °C, there are only two by-products of N2O and NO2 in the reaction system, so the general SCR denitration reaction only considers the influence of the two by-products on the main reaction [40,41]. Therefore, the development focus of low-temperature denitration catalysts should not only improve their low-temperature activity, with by-products reduced. 3.3.2 Chemical thermodynamic analysis of possible processes at different temperatures The ΔH and ΔG values at different reaction temperatures of the possible reactions at 100 and 300 °C are shown in Fig. 10 . From Fig. 10(a), when the reaction system is at 100 °C, more side reactions will occur, producing N2O, NO2, N2O3, N2O4 and N2O5 by-products, which are consistent with the results in Fig. 8(b). And this is the main reason why the general denitration reaction does not work well at low temperature. At 300 °C, as shown in Fig. 10(c), due to the increase in the Gibbs free energy of N2O3, N2O4 and N2O5, the reaction cannot proceed to the right spontaneously. So only two by-products, N2O and NO2, remain in the reaction system. Fig.10(b) and (d) both show that the reaction of N2O3, N2O4 and N2O5 with NH3 will be more spontaneous than N2O, NO and NO2 if by-products are formed, which is due to the higher oxidizing of N2O3, N2O4 and N2O5. 3.3.3 Chemical thermodynamic analysis on catalyst The detailed parameters for the reaction of NH3 and NOx with the catalyst CuOx/C were obtained using the reaction equation module in HSC Chemistry 6.0, respectively. ΔH and ΔG of reaction temperature are shown in Fig. 10. It can be seen from the XPS results that there is no elemental Cu before and after the reaction, so the catalyst is mainly in the form of metal oxides of Cu, which can be reflected in both XRD and XPS. Therefore, the reaction on the catalyst is mainly the reaction with CuO and Cu2O. The chemical equation of the oxidation reaction is shown in Eq. (1), and the reduction reaction is shown in (2)–(4). Thus, reactions without oxygen participation such as (5)–(7) can be obtained [42]. However, in general, there will be oxygen in the reaction system, as shown in formulas (8)–(10) [43]. The oxidation reaction of NH3 on the catalyst, (1) N H 3 ( g ) + 3 CuO = 3 / 2 C u 2 O + 1 / 2 N 2 ( g ) + 3 / 2 H 2 O ( g ) Reduction of NOx on the catalyst, (2) N 2 O ( g ) + C u 2 O = 2 CuO + N 2 ( g ) (3) NO ( g ) + C u 2 O = 2 CuO + 1 / 2 N 2 ( g ) (4) N O 2 ( g ) + 2 C u 2 O = 4 CuO + 1 / 2 N 2 ( g ) The reaction of NOx and NH3 on the catalyst, (5) N 2 O ( g ) + 2 / 3 N H 3 ( g ) = 4 / 3 N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (6) NO ( g ) + 2 / 3 N H 3 ( g ) = 5 / 6 N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (7) N O 2 ( g ) + 4 / 3 N H 3 ( g ) = 7 / 6 N 2 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( g ) The reaction of NOx and NH3 on the catalyst with O2 added, (8) N 2 O ( g ) + 2 N H 3 ( g ) + O 2 ( g ) = 2 N 2 ( g ) + 3 H 2 O ( g ) (9) NO ( g ) + N H 3 ( g ) + 1 / 4 O 2 ( g ) = N 2 ( g ) + 3 / 2 H 2 O ( g ) (10) N O 2 ( g ) + 2 N H 3 ( g ) + 1 / 2 O 2 ( g ) = 3 / 2 N 2 ( g ) + 3 H 2 O ( g ) Fig. 11 (a) and (b) show that the oxidation reaction on the catalyst is mainly the conversion of NH3 to N2, while (c) and (d) are the reduction of NOx on the catalyst. And before 508 °C, the conversion of by-product NO2 takes precedence over N2O in the system, with side reactions taking precedence over main reaction. 4 Conclusion The Cu-BTC derived catalyst from the precursor synthesized at room temperature has good denitration performance. The catalyst CuOx/C prepared at calcination time of 3 h and calcination temperature of 450 °C has a denitration performance, with the denitration rate around 80% at 240 °C and more than 90% up 300 °C. The reaction mechanism can be inferred through material characterization and theoretical calculations: The characterization of materials shows that CuOx/C has both CuO and Cu2O crystal phase structures, and the Cu2O crystal phase structure gradually decreases with the increase of calcination temperature. After calcination, the proportion of Cu element in the catalyst increased, and the catalyst retained the characteristic peaks of organic ligands in the precursor raw materials. And meanwhile, the coexistence of an appropriate amount of Cu+ and Cu2+ will form electron pairs and accelerate the redox cycle, thereby increasing the denitration activity of catalysts. From the calculation of HSC software that under the SCR reaction conditions, when the system is at 100 °C, more side reactions will occur, engendering by-products of N2O, NO2, N2O3, N2O4 and N2O5. While at 300 °C, due to the increases of the Gibbs free energy of N2O3, N2O4 and N2O5, the reaction cannot proceed spontaneously to the right, only two by-products N2O and NO2 remain in the system. Therefore, the SCR reaction is mainly based on the catalytic reduction of NO, N2O and NO2 with NH3 on the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Solvent or hydrothermal synthesis of MOF requires more energy. Therefore, based on the synthesis of MOF at room temperature, CuOx/C catalyst was prepared by calcination, and related researches were carried out with the goal of removing NOx. The effects of different calcination time and calcination temperature on the denitration performance of the catalyst were studied, and the optimal preparation conditions were screened. And through the characterization and analysis of XRD, FTIR, SEM and XPS, the difference in denitration performance of the catalyst under different calcination conditions was explained. Combined with the calculation of HSC Chemistry software, it is shown that NO would react differently on the catalyst at different temperatures. Which was also an important reason for the need to improve the selectivity of catalysts at low temperatures. Environmental Implication NOx is one of the main gas pollutants, and the current treatment method mainly uses ammonia gas as a reducing agent to remove it under the action of the catalyst. Through the action of catalyst, NOx can react with ammonia gas to generate harmless nitrogen gas.
coredata.dc:title: Chemical thermodynamic and catalytic mechanism analysis of Cu-BTC-derived CuOx/C catalyst for selective catalytic reduction (SCR)
